theory.intro: <par>Sometimes we have multiple equations with multiple variables. How does that work? And how can we solve all equations together?</par>
theory.systemsOfEquations: <head>Systems of equations</head><par>Suppose that we go to the market to buy fruit. First we get eight apples and six bananas for nine euros. Later on, realizing we actually need more, we go back and get another two apples and five bananas, this time paying four euros. Based on this info, can we determine how much individual apples and bananas cost?</par><par>The story above can be translated into equations. Similarly, we can turn our second fruit stall visit into an equation too, giving <block-math/> Our goal now is to find a combination of values for <inline-math/> and <inline-math/> that satisfies <emp>all</emp> of the given equations. We call such a set of equations a <term>system of equations</term> and the combination of values for the variables that matches all equations is known as the <term>solution</term> of the system. Finding it is known as <term>solving</term> the system of equations.</par>
